questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is an example of a polypeptide hormone?
questions.explanation: Parathyroid hormone (PTH) is an example of a polypeptide hormone. Cortisol is a steroid hormone. Adrenaline and thyroxine are derivatives of the amino acid tyrosine.

questions.question: Question 2: Which hormone crosses the plasma membrane for its action?
questions.explanation:
Thyroxine crosses the plasma membrane for its action. Thyroid hormones enter the nucleus and bind to thyroid hormone receptors. The 
hormone-receptor complex in the nucleus binds to DNA via zinc fingers. This increases the 
expression of a variety of different genes that code for proteins regulating cell function. Although 
thyroxine is an AA derivative, there are transporters to move it into the cell, hence they are 
intracellular receptors acting on the nucleus. Epinephrine, glucagon, and insulin bind to cell surface receptors.

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following hormone is not stored before release?
questions.explanation:
26 
Sold by @itachibot Cortisol is not stored before release. Usually, the polypeptide and protein hormones such as insulin, thyroxine or renin are stored in 
secretory vesicles before release. They are synthesized as much larger polypeptide chains 
(preprohormones) that are biologically inactive and then processed intracellularly by specific 
proteases to yield the final hormone molecule which is stored in the secretory vesicle until needed. On the other hand, steroid hormones such as cortisol are synthesised as needed and are not 
stored. They are lipid soluble and easily diffuse across cell membrane to enter the interstitial fluid 
and then blood.

questions.question: Question 4: Downregulation of receptors occurs due to all except
questions.explanation:
Downregulation of receptors occurs due to internalisation, inactivation of receptors or 
desensitisation. A decrease in the level of stimulating hormones generally leads to an increase in the level of active 
receptors. This is called upregulation of receptors. On the other hand, an increase in the level of stimulating hormones generally leads to a decrease 
in the level of active receptors. This is called downregulation of receptors. Downregulation of receptors can occur by one of the following mechanisms: • Desensitisation - Receptors undergo chemical modifications that make them less responsive. • Internalisation - It is the temporary sequestration of the cell membrane receptors to the inside of 
the cell, away from the action of hormones. Following internalisation, the receptors are either 
destroyed or recycled. • Inactivation of receptors. • Decreased production of receptors.

questions.question: Question 5: Receptors on cell membrane that activate ion channel after binding with agonists are
questions.explanation:
Nicotinic cholinergic receptors activate an ion channel after binding with its agonist. These 
receptors are called ligand-gated channels or ionotropic receptors. Receptors for neurotransmitters are classified into two broad families based on structure and 
function. They are: • Ligand-gated channels (Ionotropic receptors) • When bound to these receptors, a membrane channel is opened leading to a brief increase in 
ionic conductance. • Important for fast synaptic transmission. • Examples - GABAA, GABAC, Nicotinic cholinergic, Glycine and Serotonin (5HT3 subtype). • G-protein coupled receptors (Metabotropic receptors) 27 
Sold by @itachibot • When bound to these receptors, secondary messengers are released that modulate voltage-gated 
channels on neuronal membranes. • Examples - GABAB, Muscarinic cholinergic, Catecholamines, Serotonin (all subtypes except 
5HT3) and opioid receptors.

questions.question: Question 6: Adrenaline, noradrenaline and dopamine act through
questions.explanation:
Adrenaline, noradrenaline and dopamine act through a 7 pass receptor called G-protein coupled 
receptor (GPCR). The catecholamines act through GPCRs which are cell membrane receptors that span across the 
membrane 7 times hence called seven helix or serpentine receptors.

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following statements is true about the G-protein-coupled receptor (GPCR)?

options.a: G proteins bind to hormones on the surface of the nucleus.
options.b: All the three subunits  , , and ■ should bind to each other for G proteins to act.
options.c: G proteins act as inhibitory or excitatory because of differences in  subunit.
options.d: G protein is bound to GTP in resting state.

questions.explanation:
G proteins act as inhibitory or excitatory because of differences in  subunit. G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) are cell membrane receptors that span across the membrane 
7 times hence called seven helix or serpentine receptors. G proteins have 3 subunits ( , and ■). In its resting state,  subunit is bound to GDP. Upon ligand binding to GPCR, it undergoes a conformational change that activates G protein 
within the cell. The  subunit dissociates and in turn alters the activity of second messengers such 
as cAMP, cGMP or Ca2+. Once the ligand is unbound, the intrinsic GTPase activity of the  subunit converts GTP to GDP. 
This leads to reassociation of  with the -■ subunit and termination of effector activation. 28 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 8: Action of  subunit of G protein is
questions.explanation:
The action of  subunit of G protein is the breakdown of GTP to GDP as it has an intrinsic GTPase 
activity. Guanine exchange factors (GEFs) convert GDP to GTP by nucleotide exchange. G proteins can be either stimulatory (GS) or inhibitory (Gi) with respect to the production of the 
2nd messenger cAMP by the enzyme adenylyl cyclase. Stimulatory or inhibitory activity resides in 
the  subunit. • Cholera toxin acts on  subunit of GS • Pertussis toxin acts on  subunit of Gi

questions.question: Question 9: PDGF acts through which of the following signaling pathways?
questions.explanation:
PDGF (platelet-derived growth factor) acts through the activation of tyrosine kinases. All growth factors that foster the multiplication or development of various types of cells act 
through the activation of tyrosine kinases.

questions.question: Question 10: Which hormone acts on JAK-STAT kinase receptor?
questions.explanation:
Growth hormone acts on JAK-STAT receptors. Janus tyrosine kinase receptors (JAK-STAT) serves as receptors for: • Growth hormone • Prolactin • Erythropoietin 29 
Sold by @itachibot • Leptin Thyroxine acts on nuclear receptors. TSH and FSH act on G protein-coupled receptors.

questions.question: Question 11: All of the following act through cell surface receptors except
questions.explanation: Cortisol is a steroid hormone and acts on intracellular (cytoplasmic) receptor.

questions.question: Question 12: Steroid hormone receptors have an attachment site for all except
questions.explanation:
Steroid hormone receptors have an attachment site for steroid hormone, hormone-responsive 
element, and transcription activators, but not transcription repressors. Transcription repressors are proteins that bind to specific sites on DNA and prevent transcription 
of nearby genes.

questions.question: Question 13: True statement about second messengers is

options.a: Are substances that interact with first messengers outside cells.
options.b: Mediate the intracellular responses to many different hormones and neurotransmitters
options.c: Are hormones secreted by cells in response to stimulation by another hormone
options.d: Are substances that bind to first messengers in the cell membrane.

questions.explanation:
Second messengers mediate the intracellular responses to many different hormones and 
neurotransmitters. Cell surface receptors are substances that interact with the first messengers which are hormones 
and neurotransmitters. The second messengers are the intracellular signalling molecules. They bring about many 
short-term changes in cell function by altering enzyme function, triggering exocytosis, and other 
physiological effects. They can also lead to the alteration of transcription of various genes (long 
term effect). 30 
Sold by @itachibot Examples of second messengers are cAMP, cGMP, Ca2+ and IP3-DAG (Inositol triphosphate and 
diacylglycerol).

questions.question: Question 14: Which one of the following acts as a second messenger?
questions.explanation:
Among the following calcium (Ca2+) acts as a second messenger. Increased cytoplasmic Ca2+ binds to and activates calcium-binding proteins (calmodulin, 
troponin) or activate protein kinases (or phospholipase C) to bring about physiological effects. Cytoplasmic Ca2+ is increased by: • Direct entry of Ca2+ from the ECF through Ca2+ channels that could be ligand-gated, 
voltage-gated or stretch-activated (mechanically gated). • Mobilisation of Ca2+ that are stored in high concentrations in the endoplasmic reticulum by 
other second messengers such as IP3-DAG (Inositol triphosphate and diacylglycerol).

questions.question:
Question 15: A primigravida with 38 completed weeks of gestation has gone into labor. Oxytocin was 
started to augment labor. The second messenger system through which oxytocin acts is
questions.explanation:
The second messenger system through which oxytocin acts is the phospholipase C system. It activates the enzyme phospholipase C which breaks down some phospholipids in the cell 
membrane into IP3 (phosphoinositol triphosphate) and DAG (diacylglycerol). DAG then activates 
protein kinase C and IP3 mobilises Ca2+ from mitochondria and endoplasmic reticulum to bring 
about smooth muscle contraction and other cellular responses.

questions.question: Question 16: cAMP is the exclusive second messenger for all the following except
questions.explanation:
Vasopressin does not use cAMP exclusively. Vasopressin (ADH) acts on at least 3 kinds of receptors: V1A, V1B and V2 • All the 3 are G-protein coupled receptors • V1A and V1B receptors (Gq) act through IP3 as a second messenger, to increase the intracellular 
calcium concentration • V2 receptors (Gs) use cAMP as a second messenger cAMP is the exclusive second messenger for dopamine, corticotropin and glucagon. Dopamine has 5 receptors (D1, D2, D3, D4, D5) • all use cAMP as second messengers • D1, D5 act by increasing cAMP • D2, D3, D4 act by decreasing cAMP 31 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 17: cGMP is the second messenger of
questions.explanation:
Vasodilatory actions of NO are mediated by cGMP. NO is a hormone derived from the amino acid arginine. It activates guanylyl cyclases in vascular 
smooth muscle cells resulting in the conversion of cGTP to cGMP (2nd messenger). cGMP 
activates cGMP dependent protein kinase, which causes blood vessels to relax. cGMP is the second messenger for nitric oxide and atrial natriuretic factor.

questions.question: Question 18: Which of the following is not a second messenger?
questions.explanation:
Guanylyl cyclase is the enzyme that catalyzes the formation of cGMP. It is cGMP that acts as the 
second messenger. cAMP, IP3 and DAG are all second messengers.

questions.question: Question 19: Activation of protein kinase C causes
questions.explanation:
Activation of protein kinase C causes phosphorylation of proteins Cellular Phosphorylation is under the control of two groups of proteins: • Kinases • enzymes that catalyse the phosphorylation of tyrosine or serine residues in protein • Example- Protein Kinase A, Protein Kinase C, Ca2+/Calmodulin Kinase • Phosphatases • that catalyses the dephosphorylation of tyrosine or serine residues in the protein Kinases play important roles in regulating cellular physiology, including cell growth and cell 
death. Philadelphia chromosome, t(9:22) or the bcr-abl fusion gene codes for an abnormal kinase 
that leads to chronic myeloid leukaemia (CML). The drug imatinib was developed to block the 
tyrosine kinase activity of bcr-abl protein and is an effective treatment option for CML.

questions.question:
Question 20: A 7-year-old girl presents with skin lesions as shown in the image. The parents also complain 
of early breast development, growth acceleration, and vaginal bleeding. On genetic studies, it 
was found that there is a gain of function mutation of G Protein. What is the most probable 
diagnosis? 24 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Among the given options, the most probable diagnosis is McCune-Albright syndrome as it is the 
only gain-of-function mutation of G Protein. G proteins or G protein-coupled receptor complexes can undergo a loss- or gain-of-function 
mutation. Some examples are given below: In McCune-Albright syndrome, a gain-of-function mutation in Gs is associated with the 
rough-bordered areas of skin pigmentation and hypercortisolism. This mutation occurs during 
fetal development, creating a mosaic of normal and abnormal cells. 32

questions.question: Question 21: Nuclear signalling pathways are all except
questions.explanation:
Rat proteins are not nuclear signalling pathways. Recombinant rat IFN- is a bioactive protein 
intended for use in cell culture applications. Importin: • Transporting protein molecules into nucleus by binding to specific recognition sequences, called 
Nuclear Localization Sequences (NLS). • 2 subunits, importin  and importin . Caveolins: • Family of integral membrane proteins that are principal components of caveolae membranes • Involved in receptor-independent endocytosis. • Acts as scaffolding proteins within caveolar membranes by compartmentalizing and 
concentrating signaling molecules. NF-kB • Part of a prototypical proinflammatory signaling pathway • based on the role of NF-B in the expression of proinflammatory genes including cytokines, 
chemokines, and adhesion molecules 33 
Sold by @itachibot Transport Across Cell Membrane
